data.text: Introduction
This guideline is to help the clinician dealing with a child presenting with non- traumatic limp to distinguish those at risk of serious pathology from those children with a benign cause.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to standardise the assessment and treatment of children presenting to the Paediatric Emergency Department (PED) or the Paediatric Assessment Unit (PAU) with a limp.
Definitions
PED Lead- dissemination and guideline support with implementation.
Clinical Guideline Lead EM and Paediatrics- Ensure guideline is up to date and available.
ED Clinical Team- To ensure that the due process as outlined is followed.
Paediatric Clinical Team- To ensure that the due process as outlined is followed.
Orthopaedic Clinical Team- To ensure that the due process as outlined is followed.

Limping following obvious trauma poses little diagnostic challenge and will not be dealt with in this guideline. Two common patterns of presentation exist, namely the painful hip and the acutely swollen joint.
It is important to remember a few general points when approaching the limping child.
Limping may be due to pain referred from somewhere else (genital/spinal pain referring to the hip and pain from the hip referring to the thigh or knee);
Certain causes of limping are age dependant;
Inflicted injury should always be considered.
Management of Limping Child in Emergency Department/19006/1.0
Always conduct a thorough history and general clinical examination for all children.
5.3.1 History

The history should include questions about trauma, preceding infections or drug exposure, the presence of fever, rashes, features of systemic disease with joint involvement and the rate of onset of the problem;
5.3.2 Specific examination assessments:
Gait: Antalgic gait, running usually accentuates any pathological features.
Standing: Back and spine (deformity and tenderness), pelvic tilt.

Lying supine: examine each joint separately for tenderness, swelling, effusion, erythema, warmth and range of movement: Hip rotation is the most sensitive test and should be symmetrical if there is no pathology.
Also examine abdomen and groin and look for muscle atrophy, weakness and abnormal tendon reflexes.
Differential diagnosis

Trauma (fracture, haemarthrosis, soft tissue); Infection (septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, discitis); Secondary to various viral illnesses; Tumour; Sickle cell disease; Serum sickness.
Transient synovitis Toddler's fracture Child abuse Developmental dysplasia of the hip Juvenile arthritis (pauciarticular) Neuromuscular disease Haemophilia Henoch-Schonlein purpura
Slipped upper femoral epiphysis Overuse syndromes Osteochondritis dissecans

data.text: Septic Arthritis
6.1.1 This can destroy a joint within 24 hours. Diagnosis is by exclusion. Important signs to watch for are:
Marked pain/spasm;
High fever;
Systemic upset++;
Raised ESR more than 20.
6.1.2 Remember that not all the features may be present and that the younger the child the more subtle the presentation can be.
Transient synovitis

6.2.1 This is a relatively common problem, especially in children between the ages of 3 and 6 years old which is usually self-limiting within approximately one week. There is a higher incidence in boys than girls.
Rapid onset of hip pain and limping in an otherwise well child;
+/- history of preceding viral illness;
Hip held in flexion and abduction, limitation of internal rotation;
Only mild reduction of hip movements.
Perthe's disease (osteonecrosis of the femoral head)
6.3.1 This tends to be found in the age group of 4 to  years and is due to an avascular necrosis of the femoral head. Diagnosis is radiological, but x-ray changes may be absent early in the illness:
Boys: Girls = 4:1;
15% may be bilateral;
No systemic features.
Slipped upper femoral epiphysis (SUFE)

6.4.1 This tends to occur in 10 – 15-year olds, often with body weight above the th centile. Boys are affected slightly more often than girls and nearly a quarter of patients have bilateral disease. There may or may not be a history of minimal trauma. Diagnosis is radiological:
Boys: Girls = 2;
25% may be bilateral;
AP views alone may miss subtle changes therefore bilateral ‘frog view' is required.

The differential diagnosis of an acutely swollen and painful joint is large and initial investigation is aimed at excluding conditions which require urgent treatment. If the diagnosis is still unclear after initial investigations it is essential to organize appropriate follow up. data.text: Management
(Refer to Appendix 2)
Apply EMLA cream appropriately.
Give analgesia- ibuprofen 10mg/kg if no contraindication.
Perform bloods (ESR, CRP, FBC).
Consider an x-ray of the affected joint (if following trauma, history of > one week, aged over 4 years; AP pelvis x-ray with a Frog-lateral view if child over 8 years old).
Arrange for an ultrasound scan of the hips.
An aspiration of the effusion may be considered but only after discussion with senior in ED.
Send any aspirate to microbiology for MCS (remember to phone the lab) if this has not been done by radiology.
If bloods and x-ray are normal, an ultrasound may be deferred depending on clinical suspicion.
Provided the child is systemically well (afebrile, no vomiting, appropriate analgesia) they can be reviewed in the community by the GP if no improvement after 7 days.
Cases may be discussed with paediatric registrar/ ED EPIC if any concern or query arises.
Provide Parents with written information leaflet prior to discharge, with analgesic advice and advice to return if not improving.
